MainClaim.text: "Currie's rejection of weak illusionism is sound

Untitled1.text: "Currie's rejection of weak illusionism is unjustified because he fails to present an argument for realism and merely argues against illusionism."

Untitled2.text: "Currie equivocates between proposing garden-variety motion and special response-dependent motion."

Untitled3.text: "Kania agrees with Currie that there is no illusion of physical objects in motion onscreen

Untitled4.text: "Ponech's theory that cinematic motion is external and prior to the interpretation of information by the mind is more convincing than Kania's theory."

Untitled5.text: "Kania's argument against Currie relies on a single contention

Untitled6.text: "Ponech's description of a quasi-cinematic display is accurate."

Untitled7.text: "The experience of film is the experience of seeing moving images under specific perceptual circumstances

Untitled8.text: "The view that the illusory nature of film can be proved by slowing the projector down is doubly fallacious."

Untitled9.text: "Currie's theory of cinematic motion is the most plausible of the three options."

Untitled10.text: "The discussion is about film and Currie has already identified film as essentially moving pictures."

Untitled11.text: "Cinematic motion is the real movement of singletons."

Untitled13.text: "The fact that cinematic motion is produced by static frames shows only that a certain speed of projection-24 fps-is a reception condition of the art form."

Untitled14.text: "Ponech's attempt to prove that singletons exhibit garden-variety motion fails because they are not objects and differ from objects in that their existence is dependent on perception."

Untitled15.text: "Currie's theory of cinematic motion is the most plausible of the three options."
